reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s inclusion of esoteric possibilities (acausal trade/simulation deals/infinite value) as examples of “moral catastrophe,” arguing this creates a memetic/rhetorical hazard that could increase real-world risk-taking. This is only moderately central: those examples are explicitly presented as non-exhaustive (“and so on”) and the core “no easy eutopia” case is supported by many other, much more mainstream mechanisms (population ethics, digital minds, bad aggregation, lock-in, etc.), so the thesis survives deleting the esoteric items. The argument’s strength is moderate: the mechanism (astronomical-upside laundering; extremist recruitment/grift; destabilising ideology) is plausible in principle and engages a genuine failure mode for EV/gamble framings, but it is largely conjectural, offers no concrete evidence that Forethought’s specific presentation would materially shift elite behaviour, and it doesn’t directly rebut the object-level claim that near-best futures are a narrow target. Relevance is fairly high because it bears on Forethought’s practical agenda around governance/epistemics and on cross-tier interactions between moral uncertainty/EV rhetoric and real-world power-seeking dynamics (a live concern given their emphasis on power concentration and institutional design). Overall, it raises a real communications/strategy risk but does not substantially undermine the core philosophical conclusion.
title: Rhetorical exploitation of speculative ideas increases real-world risk
